page.title: 02TRANSPORT
page.content: Running like a spine through our area, as it does for Scotland ,is the major trunk road, the A9, connecting Inverness and the north to Edinburgh and points south. Until quite recently it was also a nightmare to drive , particularly in the summer. Although leading to prosperity for the various stopping places,of which Pitlochry was one,it also led to a main street clogged with lorries and fumes,with four mile queues and nowhere to park . But the Pitlochry by-pass was opened in 1980, having taken two years to build, and costing approximately Â£1 million per kilometre to construct. On average 10,000 tonnes of vehicles travel the by-pass daily. The road has increased the tourist trade with visitors staying for longer periods in the summer due to ease of access.
